title: When someone uses an unfriendly tone of voice to speak to me, would it be appropriate for me to talk in a serious tone of voice and knit my eyebrows to send a message of disapproval? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve observed that when a person is rude, terse and altogether unfriendly, others go out of their way to kill that person - with kindness. Typically the rude person has a microscopic power advantage over others. For example, they might be the spouse of a teacher but not the actual teacher. It could be a co-worker with more experience, but not a boss. Or a customer in a store addressing the service person. Typical conversation; “Do you know how to file this paper or am I going to have to do that too?” Typical response “ yes I know how to file, in fact I won a filing competition four years in a row! (Big smile) In fact it’s already done”. More effective response, the one rude people seldom hear (lower voice, knit brows) ”are you under the impression that you have been doing more work than me?” Here’s another; “I take my break at 11:00, so don’t wander off and disappear or the phones will go unanswered.” Typical response “I’ll be glued to my desk!” along with a good natured laugh. More effective response (lower voice; knit brows) “I don’t wander off, nor do I disappear. Just be back by 11:15 when I’ll take my break”. Mean people are only nice to people who don’t put up with it. They seem to follow some kind of animal like dominence code. For some reason the knee jerk reaction to rude people is overwhelming kindness, or a cajoling peacemaking effort. Forget it, play by their rules and set your boundaries. They will love you for it.

NO. Here are some words of wisdom from 48 Laws of Power by Robert Greene. “By acknowledging a petty problem you give it existence and credibility. The more attention you pay an enemy, the stronger you make him; and a small mistake is often made worse and more visible when you try to fix it. It is sometimes best to leave things alone. If there is something you want but cannot have, show contempt for it. The less interest you reveal, the more superior you seem.” “The best lesson you can teach an irritating gnat is to consign it to oblivion by ignoring it. If it is impossible to ignore, then conspire in secret to do away with it, but never inadvertently draw attention to the bothersome insect that will go away or die on it’s own.”  Great video summary of Law no. 36 by illacertus.
